en.title: üî• 100 Hours of Native Development: Integrating Yandex Ads into React Native
en.shortDescription: A story about how the lack of a ready-made library led to a deep dive into Native Modules, Fabric Components, and native layouting.
en.content:
In spring 2022, I was part of a team developing a mobile app using React Native. Due to a lack of other resources, I got the chance to work with native modules and components. Back then I had no idea I was in for more than 100 hours of fascinating development üòÖ

From Google Ads to an urgent migration to Yandex

The initial task seemed simple: ‚ÄúIntegrate Google Ads‚Äù ‚Äî our main monetization method. We already had a tested library and prior experience.

But unexpected external events forced us to urgently migrate to Yandex Ads. That‚Äôs when the adventure began.

At that moment Yandex had only one React Native library, and it was outdated. We checked it ‚Äî some parts worked, some didn‚Äôt. Later we refactored several pieces and reused them inside our project.

Four ad formats, three integrated

First we had to analyze the documentation and understand which ad types we needed to implement. Yandex offered four formats:

  • Rewarded Ad ‚Äî fullscreen ads with a reward for watching.
  • Banner ‚Äî a small static banner at the top or bottom of the screen.
  • Fullscreen ‚Äî fullscreen ads without rewards.
  • Native (now Feed) ‚Äî an in-content card styled to match the app.

We integrated three of them: Rewarded, Fullscreen, and the most intriguing ‚Äî Native.

First steps with native modules

Rewarded and Fullscreen ads were quite straightforward, even though this was my first experience with the native side of RN. We needed to create React Native Native Modules (official docs). TurboModules weren‚Äôt the default yet.

I quickly built a basic example, verified functionality on both iOS and Android, implemented the required methods, compiled the modules, and tested everything in RN. No major issues: essentially just calling native SDKs through the bridge, and the ads appeared on top of the UI without interacting with it.

Diving into Fabric Native Components: native ads

But Native Ads were far more interesting. According to the documentation, their display requirements were extremely strict: if conditions weren‚Äôt met, impressions would not be counted, directly impacting monetization.

What was required?

We had to embed a native ad card directly into the app feed ‚Äî and style it so it blended naturally with the rest of the list items. The feed used a masonry layout, looking something like this:

Sounds simple ‚Äî just lay out a card. But not really.

The first issue appeared immediately: the layout had to be fully native ‚Äî XML on Android, Storyboard/StoryboardKit on iOS. That was new to me, and it took quite some time to shape the cards properly.

But how to integrate all this into React Native? Back then there was almost no information on Native Components. The only useful resources I found were a Sbermarket article and a talk.

Today the documentation on Native Components is abundant. There are even ready-to-use examples on GitHub. If only we had that back then... link

The cards rendered fine: skeleton loader, ad loading‚Ä¶ but the joy didn‚Äôt last. Components began overflowing with content. First shock, then denial, then bargaining ‚Äî the full cycle üòÖ

Eventually it became clear: we had to compute dynamic card height. I ended up writing a function on the Fiber level to measure component size based on image dimensions and text line count ü§™.

After many iterations we finally achieved stable behavior for native ads. A couple of years later, an official React Native library was released ‚Äî but that's another story üôÇ

Summary

The Yandex Ads integration turned out to be a remarkable challenge: from initial work with Native Modules to deep exploration of Fabric Native Components and native layouting. Despite the complexity, the experience proved invaluable and offered a strong understanding of how React Native interacts with platform-level UI components.

en.title: ü™ñ Battle-Tested Experience with NFC Cards and MultiChain Wallets
en.shortDescription: Building NFC workflows, designing a scalable multichain wallet and leading a hybrid engineering team as a CTO.
en.content:
In the second half of 2025, I had the chance to work hands-on on a project that blended two domains rarely found in the same sentence: IoT and Web3. Despite a fairly busy CTO schedule, I wanted to stay involved technically ‚Äî and this project offered more than enough opportunities.

IoT: Getting NFC cards to behave

Together with a colleague, we tackled a full cycle of working with NFC cards: activating them, taking them out of transport mode, creating directories, configuring files with various access levels. I developed software that later served as a remote tool for factories in Russia and China. With its help, we processed more than five thousand NFC cards. By the end of it, I could almost tell what state a card was in just by the sound of the reader ‚Äî a skill that, surprisingly, is not yet listed on LinkedIn.

Web3: Designing a multichain wallet that grows without friction

The Web3 part of the project focused on designing the architecture of a scalable multichain wallet. The long-term goal was clear: support many networks without rewriting half the system each time. I manually implemented around ten networks myself and designed a unified approach for extending networks that run on the same virtual machine, such as EVM-compatible chains. I've achieved the point where networks running on a single VM can be added in a couple of hours.. Under my guidance, the team added support for nearly twenty networks, with a few more underway.

Management: Leading a hybrid team while wearing multiple hats

From a management standpoint, the project was just as interesting. As a CTO, I couldn‚Äôt be fully dedicated to development, so I assembled a mixed team of in-house engineers and project-based specialists. Over time, the composition changed ‚Äî which is normal for a growing project ‚Äî and eventually we arrived at a strong, well-balanced team with the right combination of technical and communication skills. When the structure solidified, I handed the project over to the team lead and shifted into a supervisory role.

Looking back, the project brought together engineering, architecture, coordination and a fair amount of cross-timezone problem solving. A demanding experience, but also one of the most rewarding.
